So, if I follow your argument, because Tesla provides "Free" re-charging somehow that power ISN'T coming from a coal or natural gas plant?

Here's the thing:
Virtually all new electric generating capacity for the coasts coming online is either natural gas or coal. (Nuclear is falling as plants come offline.) That electrical grid is what charges your Tesla. Your Tesla is coal or natural gas powered. QID

The problem with the Tesladvocates is always that they have a tough time separating the "subsidies" (and the Model S is crawling with subsidies) from the underlying physics.

I can't think of a better place to dump excess energy that the waiting fleets of EVs. If that energy is not solar than it could very likely be wind powered generators, two systems that have overlap in output and can co-exist beautifully. The weak link in this chain is the antiquated electrical grid we have. Time to fix, repair or replace our infrastructure.

Where do you get your statements that you cite like they are reality?  They are not and any person can do just a little research to prove you completely wrong.  Is the Tesla Model S completely clean?  Of course not.  The question is whether it is cleaner than your typical gas car.  The answer is a clear yes.  Even if it is run from 100% coal derived energy it will still beat every car in it's class.  The oil companies would like you to believe otherwise because they have a vested interest in seeing an electric car fail.  That is where you got your propoganda.  Here's the other thing, you can make the electrical grid cleaner.  Oil will not get cleaner.  In fact it's getting a lot more dirty now it's becoming harder to get and the oil companies are switching to alternative ways to pull it out of the ground.  Further, with solar panels on your roof, you have the ability to power your car from the comfort of your own home and be completely independent from energy.  When was the last time you filled up your gas tank from your personal oil well?  Electricity has many many ways to be gathered and a lot that are quite clean.  You don't get that choice with oil and gasoline.  So you'd prefer us all to have less choices?  No one has said you have to buy this car just stop saying unfounded things to try and convince the rest of us we should stick with something we all know isn't good for us or the country.

To all those commenting about the "Tesla weaning us from fossil fuels"...
You do realize that these Tesla Model S autos are largely charged at night (when there is no solar being pumped into the grid) so are primarily fueled by natural gas and coal power plants?

On a marginal energy contribution analysis these cars run on fossil fuels just as surely as the S-Class or 7-series it seeks to replace. It's a tremendous technical achievement but, like the Leaf, not nearly as green as it pretends to be. Of course, for the folks on the CA coast where I see Teslas all the time-- they have the self-satisfaction that comes from pretending to be green AND exporting their pollution to Red-State havens like Utah, Arizona and Texas where the coal plants are that feed this nonsense.

Leadership changes are a start. What is needed next are clear, actionable guidelines for evaluating 501(c)(4) applications based on an organization's activities, rather than its affiliations or philosophy. I agree that the IRS was inept rather than conspiracy minded, but the ineptitude resulted in an inappropriate singling-out of Tea Party and similar groups. The administration deserves a black eye for the original offense, but praise for moving to correct the situation.

Side note: I belong to a small community organization that submitted a 501(c)(4) application to the IRS in October 2012. As of May 2013, we are still waiting for a response from the IRS. We are not engaged in electoral politics-- our primary activities are on literacy, homelessness and elder care. I guess we are waiting in a long line of applications to be processed. The 501(c)(4) tax exemption is worthwhile-- it helps groups like mine, as well as Kiwanis, the Elks, the Rotary Club and similar bodies. Prompt, impartial IRS credentialing is important.

Satyajit ray, whether he knew it or not, paid his own tribute to Macaulay in Aparajito (the second film in the Apu Trilogy) in one of the most luminous scenes in film history. Apu was learning geography in school, had read about strange and exotic peoples, and a whole world had opened up literally and figuratively. Ray accomplished this by showing the spinning globe in the classroom and then in quick succession scenes from the world as imagined by Apu.

That geography lesson was there thanks to Macaulay, thanks earlier to European pedagogy that had made a discipline of geography, and thanks ultimately to European civilization that had become curious about the world and had gone exploring. In that same decade of the 1830s that the 30-something Macaulay was in India, a 20-something Darwin was on the Beagle and drawing startling conclusions that are to this day unacceptable to most people, even card carrying liberal scientists, if they are probed enough.

India made its own contributions to world knowledge. The rules of arithmetic, addition, multiplication and long division that children learn around the world is the gift of India.

Cultural superiority, a product of various accidents of history, has nothing to do with racial or ethnic superiority. We all left Africa some 60 thousand years ago to populate the world and there has been no neurological change in our brains since.

It doesn't matter where the name Hindus came from (no idea whether you are correct). All groups are labeled by themselves or others. A group is not illegitimate based on where the label came from. Each person is the genetic product of their ancestors, whatever they may have been labeled. We choose what we call ourselves and others (not always consistently). Who are Americans? At one time mostly from Britain, but certainly not anymore. But the Brits are made up of a number of groups. You could argue that there are no Americans (even the Indians came from somewhere and can be broken up into diverse groups). "Russians" and "Chinese" too can be broken up into ethnic enclaves. So what? All that matters is whether they or others consider them a group at some given time. Who are the Israelis? The Palestinians? The idea of Hispanics as a group in America seems entirely artificial to me because it is based on language, but it is still accepted. Islam is a religion too, not an ethnicity. I have no great knowledge of Muslims in India but I'd be very surprised if they weren't the same as everyone else and could not be broken up based on their ethnicity.

Also, though the Times is liberal in its politics, I don't see that they censor conservatives. I suspect they sometimes censor criticism of themselves or their writers, but I could be wrong.

Last, I replied to your comment because I thought your statement about "Hindus" was slanted. I don't have an opinion about Modi.

David, the fact is that "Hindu" is an artificial label which conjures up an imaginary homogeneity which isn't there. Just as Native Americans are perfectly legitimate in wanting to throw off the "Indian" label in calling themselves First Nations, likewise so-called Hindus don't want to be pigeon-holed into a "big bad scary monolith" by those with ulterior motives who would veer towards defining them that way. How do you get hundreds(?), thousands(?) of gods by being a monolith? Is there even any consensus on how many deities there are in so-called "Hinduism"? No, because it isn't a single religion with any single origin. The scary monolith argument is just the latest new spin on Brown Peril.

I can't help but notice how Mustafi casually inserts phrases like "right-wing" and "alleged" for spin purposes. It promotes dialogue, adopts ideas from its opponents, and gives them an opportunity for input (or for sabotage of a disliked policy). Dubya was unrestrained. He forced through radical tax cuts that undid Clinton's balanced budget., got rid of US Attorneys who were not finding or prosecuting enough voting fraud, massaged information until he got us to invade Iraq, and many more.

An administration that is too restrained gets nothing done. How long did it take us to finally catch Madoff? We would be better off with federal regulators expanding their reach than with them writing wimpy, unworkably complex rules that stop very little and mainly provide employment opportunities for creative lawyers and accountants.

A restrained, reserved, ineffective government is an invitation to anarchy. What better cover for anarchy than a government painted despotic and thereby rendered toothless?
